Wherein is contain'd The Act of ATTAINDER Past at Dublin in May, 1689.
AS ALSO The Proclamation for Raising Twenty thousand Pounds per Mensem, without an Act of Parliament.
WITH Other Proclamations and Acts made There.
LONDON, Printed for Robert Clavell, Jonathan Robinson, and Joseph Watts, Booksellers in S. Pauls Church-Yard, 1690.

div.head: AN ACCOUNT OF THE Transactions OF THE LATE KING JAMES IN IRELAND.
div.p:
SInce my repair into England, whither I in the Month of May last made my Escape with the manifest peril of my Life, being surrounded with a Thousand Difficulties and Hazards, I encountred another Affliction of a different temper and complexion, and such as I little suspected to find among the Inhabitants of this happy Country. Had my Conversation been among Bigotted Papists (of whose Society I was never very fond); had I hapned into the Herd of desperate Malecontents, whose sordid
complyance with the exorbitant Infractions of the Municipal Laws, and the arbitrary Invasions of all Civil Rights, during the despotical Tyranny of the late Reign had hardned them in their Apostacy, and rendred them as uncapable of Conviction, as they are unworthy of Mercy: I should either have withdrawn my self from such unseasonable Picqueering, or with a Christian Compassion lamented their incorrigible Obstinacy and Defection. But sometime Business, sometime Curiosity leading me to a frequency of Converse, and a variety of New Faces, I became astonished to hear and observe many Persons (professing the Protestant Religion) so shamefully abandon'd to a perverse and degenerate sense of the late miraculous Revolution, and an uneasie restlesness under the Auspicious Government of a Protestant King and Queen.

But when among their Sophistical Arguments I overheard them urge the Actions and Behaviour of the late King in Ireland, the Tranquility of the Protestants there, and their Immunity from the Rigor of the Laws, and the Violence and Rapine of the Souldiers, as an invincible Proof of his Goodness and Moderation, and a demonstrative Induction to Cajole the good People of England into an Expectation of Peace and Felicity, by his Restitution to the Throne; my Admiration was turn'd into Extasie, and I became equally distorted with the emotions of Pity and Rage. And tho' I believe the number of those State Hereticks to be but inconsiderable, compared with the vast multitude of Persons well-affected to the present Government; yet I thought it my Duty to oppose these mistaken Principles, and (laying aside the consideration of all the Topicks drawn from the Doctrin of Non-Resistance, Passive Obedience, and such unpracticable Notions) to apply my self, as near as I can, to the Affairs of Ireland, and to endeavour to disabuse the World, and rectifie the erronious Apprehensions of such Men, as ignorantly applaud the Government and publick Managery of Matters in that most unfortunate Kingdom. In the Recounting whereof, it will be no presumption in me to bespeak an entire Credit to be given to what I shall hereafter relate; since the whole Narration shall be composed of such
Particulars as are evidently deduc'd from Public Acts and Proclamations, or shall be justified against all Contradiction, by a positive avowing of what I have seen and heard.

I shall begin where the Late King began at his first Arrival in Ireland, when to Ingratiate himself with the Protestants, and to beget an Opinion of his great Clemency among the People, he very graciously condescended to grant a General and Free Pardon to the Inhabitants of the Town of Bandon, amusing them with an assurance of an absolute Indemnity for their Transgressions; but soon after to gratifie the Malice of those Furious Zealots (who have plainly distracted that unfortunate Prince) he remitted them to the severity of the Law, and expos'd them to a Trial for their Lives, upon which they were all found guilty of High Treason; and no other Consequence could rationally be expected, when both Judges and Jury were composed of inexorable Papists; and in the mean time this mighty Crime, which was the Object of the Kings Mercy, and an Instance of the Cruelty and Injustice of his Subjects, was no more than that the Inhabitants of the Place observing their Neighbours to be openly Robb'd and Pillag'd, and clandestine Thievery to proceed to violent Depredation, they thought it prudent to shut their Gates, and avoid Plunder by a necessary Defence and Self-preservation. This was the first Essay of the gracious Indulgence of a Popish King to his Protestant Subjects. This was a plain Specimen of what is to be expected from him who will Mortgage his Reason to the humor of his Priests.

The Business of Sir Thomas Southwell is altogether of another nature; and as the repetition of it may justly cause an abhorrence of those Blood-Suckers, who delight in the Torment and Ruine of such as they call Hereticks; so the Example may admonish all Men of Note and Degree, not to truckle their Authority in Vassalage to their Servants and Inferiours. The Earl of Seaforth taking a particular Fancy to Sir Thomas Southwell, a very hopeful young Gentleman (and under Condemnation for his reputed Rebellion) procur'd a Warrant from the Late King to Sir Richard Nagle his Attorney General, to pass a
Pardon for him, which the said Earl shewed to Sir Richard; but he in a most unmannerly and churlish fashion refused to obey it; saying, It was more than the King could do. The Earl returned to his Master, and reported the Answer of the Attorney General; who being sent for, own'd it to the King, and positively told him, It was not in his power to grant him a Pardon; whereupon the Poor Prince was overcome with Grief and Passion, and lock'd himself up in his Closet. This stiffness of the Surly Attorney General was grounded on the Act of Attainder, past in their Parliament, whereby that King is debar'd from the Prerogative of Pardoning, and the Subject foreclosed from all expectation of Mercy, as may be seen by the said Act hereafter in its due place. He who in England was flatter'd into a conceit of an absolute and unlimited Power to dispense with the Establish'd Laws, is not allowed in Ireland the Priviledge inherent to all Sovereign Powers by the Law of Nations, to pardon the Offences of a Subject. But even in this it has appeared (as by several other Instances) that he is permitted to pardon any Crime in a Roman Catholic; but in relation to a Protestant Heretick the Law is indispensible.

And what Favour Protestants are to expect under a Popish King, and in a Kingdom where Popery is predominant, let all Men judge by their procedure in Ireland, where almost all the Churches (where the Irish Arms were prevalent) except in Dublin, were seised by Authority, the Protestant Ministers Deprived, and Popish Priests Setled and Inducted into Livings and Ecclesiastical Preferments. And that I may not be suspected to talk at Random, the Reader may for his further satisfaction peruse two several Acts past in their Parliament, whereby all Popish Priests and Dignitaries are vested in the perception of Tithes, and all other Ecclesiastical Dues: And tho' these Acts seem to have a direct aspect only on the Roman Catholicks, yet they squint upon the Protestants, who having no Ministers of their own to whom they might pay their Tithes, would be obliged to pay the Tenth part to the Predominant Party, to whose arbitrary Power and Will the other Nine Parts are subjected. The Acts are as followeth:

div.head: An Act concerning Tithes, and other Ecclesiastical Duties.
div.p: WHereas Tithes, Oblations, Obventions, Offerings, and other Ecclesiastical Duties and Profits growing and arising within all and every the respective Parish and Parishes of this Kingdom, (Impropriate Tithes excepted) have by the Law of the Land, and Constitution of Holy Church, ever since the Council of Lateran, been due and payable to the respective Pastors, Curates and Vicars of the said respective Parishes, having Cure of Souls therein; as a Provision and Maintenance for them for serving the said Cure, by celebrating Divine Service, Administring of Sacraments, Preaching and Instructing the Parishioners thereof in the true Faith, and performing other Pastoral Duties belonging to their Functions.

Forasmuch as the Roman Catholick Subjects of this Kingdom for some time past have maintained their own Priests, Pastors, Curats and Vicars, and thereby have been very much impoverished, by being obliged to pay their Tithes and other Ecclesiastical Duties, to the Protestant Clergy, who have not laboured in the Administration of any of the said Spiritual Offices for any of the said Roman Catholicks.

Be it therefore Enacted, and it is hereby Enacted by your most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and the Commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by Authority of the same, That your Majesties Roman Catholick Subjects of this Kingdom, shall and may set out and pay all their Tithes, Oblations, Obventions, and other Ecclesiastical Duties (which of right are due and payable from henceforth to their respective Roman Catholick Priests, Pastors, Curats and Vicars, and to no other Person or Persons, of whatsoever Religion or Perswasion soever, (Impropriate Tithes excepted) any Law or Custom to the contrary notwithstanding.
Provided always, and it is hereby further Enacted, That all and every Person and Persons of the said Roman Catholick Clergy, who shall be Entituled to any Tithes, or Payments in lieu of Tithes, by virtue of this Act, or otherwise, and their Proctors and Farmers, shall and may sue for the same, or the value thereof, by Writ, Bill, Petition, or Action of Debt, or such other Action for Substraction, or not setting forth the said Tithes in any of your Majesties Courts within this Kingdom, as heretofore they might have done, for detaining or not paying any Temporal Duty; and shall and may recover their Costs in such Suits, and all Incapacities heretofore devised by any Temporal Law, for disabling any of the said Roman Catholick Clergy from enjoying any Benefices or Tithes, or making any Collations or Benefices to them conferred, void, are hereby discharged and made void to all intents and purposes.

div.head: Another Act concerning Appropriate Tithes, and other Duties payable to Ecclesiastical Dignitaries.
div.p: WHereas by an Act past in this present Session of Parliament, Entituled, An Act concerning Tithes and other Ecclesiastical Duties, It is amongst other things Enacted, That the Roman Catholick Subjects of this Kingdom shall and may, for ever, pay their respective Tithes (Impropriate Tithes excepted) and their respective Oblations, Obventions, and other their Ecclesiastical Dues and Duties, to their respective Roman Catholick Priests and Pastors, Curates and Vicars; to whom also Remedy is given by the said Act for recovering the same.

And whereas within this Kingdom there are several Appropriate Tithes formerly belonging to Archbishops, Bishops, Deans, Deans and Chapter, Collegiate Churches, Arch-Deacons, Prebends, and other Ecclesiastical Dignitaries: And whereas a Doubt did arise, Whether the Roman Catholicks, who are to pay such Appropriate Tithes, are by the said Act to pay the same to their respective Roman Catholick Priests, Pastors, Curates and Vicars, who are Incumbents within the respective Parishes where such Appropriate Tithes are due, to the respective Roman Catholick Dignitaries, within such Parishes or Places were such Tithes are payable.

And it is hereby Declared and Enacted by the Kings most Excellent Majesty, by the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons in this present Parliament Assembled, and by Authority of the same, That the Roman Catholicks of this Kingdom, who are to pay any such Appropriate Tithes, shall from time to time, and at all times hereafter, for ever, pay the same to the respective Roman Catholick Archbishops, Bishops, Deans, Deans and Chapter, Collegiate Churches, Archdeacons, Prebends, or other Roman Catholick Dignitaries, that are or shall be Roman Catholick Dignitaries, within the Parishes or Places where such Tithes are or shall be payable in such manner as the same were formerly paid since the Reformation, to the respective Protestant Archbishops, Bishops, Deans, Deans and Chapter, Collegiate Churches, Archdeacons, Prebends, or other Ecclesiastical Protestant Dignitaries of such Parishes or Places: And that the said respective Roman Catholick Archbishops, Bishops, Deans, Deans and Chapter, Collegiate Churches, Archdeacons, Prebends, and other Roman Catholick Dignitaries, shall have the same, or the like Remedy, for the respective Recovery of such Appropriate Tithes, as the said respective Roman Catholick Priests, Pastors, Curates and Vicars, have or shall have, for the recovery of the Tithes, payable to them respectively by virtue of the said former Act, any thing in the said former Act to the contrary notwithstanding.

And whereas it may be a Doubt, who shall be deemed, taken or reputed to be Roman Catholick Archbishops, Bishops, Deans, Archdeacons, or other Roman Catholick Dignitaries, Priests, Pastors, Curates and Vicars, within the meaning of this, or the said former Act. Be it hereby Enacted by the Authority aforesaid, That such Roman Catholick Archbishops, Bishops, and Deans, now in being, as His Majesty by any Instrument under his Privy Signet and Sign Manual, shall signifie to be Roman Catholick Archbishops, or Bishops of any Diocess, or Deans of such Places or Churches within this Realm, shall be reputed, taken and deemed the respective Roman Catholick Archbishops and Bishops of such Diocess, and Deans of such Places within this Realm: And that such Person and Persons as hereafter shall be Roman Catholick Archbishops, or Bishops of any Diocess within this Kingdom, or Dean of any Place or Church, shall be such, and no other, as shall be respectively Ordained Archbishops, or Bishops of such Diocess, or Deans of such Places or Churches, by the Nomination or Presentation of His Majesty, his Heirs and Successors; and that such shall be deemed Roman Catholick Archdeacons, Prebends, or other Roman Catholick Dignitaries; and such shall be deemed Roman Catholick Priests, Pastors, Curates and Vicars, as have been, or shall be allowed and approved of by the Roman Catholick Archbishop of the Diocess, where he or they did or shall Officiate, or they respectively shall be approved of, or allowed by the Roman Catholick Metropolitan of the Province where such Diocess doth lie, in case there was, or there is, or there shall be no Roman Catholick Bishop in being, of such Diocess, at the time of such allowance or approbation.

And be it further Enacted, That the King's Majesty, his Heirs and Successors, and all such as are, or shall be Roman Catholick Archbishops, Bishops, or other Roman Catholick Dignitaries within this Kingdom, and their Successors; and all Roman Catholick Lords, Knights, Gentlemen, or others, and their Heirs and Assigns respectively, who have, or shall have any Advowson, Collation, or Right of Presentation, Nomination,
or Collation to any Benifice within the Realm, shall for ever hereafter upon vacancy of any such Benifice, have full Power and Authority to present or Collate a fit Person, to be the Roman Catholick Dignitary, Curate, Vicar, or Pastor of such Benifice, in such manner and form as they respectively, or any of their Predecessors, or Ancestors, did or could have lawfully done.

And be it further Enacted, That so much of any Statute as tends to disable, or incapacitate any of the said Roman Catholick Archbishops, Bishops, Deans, Deacons, Archdeacons, Prebends, or any other Roman Catholick Dignitaries, Priests, Pastors, or Vicars of the Roman Catholick Church, from receiving, having, holding, or enjoying any of the said Ecclesiastical Dignites, or livings, in manner aforesaid, be and is hereby repealed and made void.

It is a matter not unworthy the observation, how dexterously the Government there could prevaricate in their dealings with the poor enslaved Protestants. For upon any apprehension of Succors arriving from England, or other pretext to fleece and squeeze them, an Information was presently given, how numerous the Protestants were, and what danger may arise from thence; and then they were fortwith confined, and hurried away to Prison, and their Houses and Goods exposed to the Rapine of the Irish and French: At another time, when it might be subservient to their designs, to lessen their number and undervalue the strength of the Protestants; then they give out that their number was but small, and their Interest inconsiderable: And this is very remarkable in a late passage at the City of Limerick, where the Cabal of the Papists projecting to get the the Churches (there) into their Hands, Represented to the King and Council, that the Protestants in that place were so very few, that there was no need to assign them any more, than one Church for their meeting; and this Suggestion was fortified by a Letter from the Earl of Limerick attesting the same; but when the business came to be examined, it appeared
to be so gross and palpable a Delusion, that their King himself saw through it, and discovered the Imposture; and out of meer shame dismist the Petitioners without any success in their Application.

If at any time, an Information was given to the Government of any Mony or Plate, or other things valuable in the Hands of a Protestant, thô guarded by the solemnity of a Protection; this was soon seconded by the suspicion of some Plot against the Government, and immediatly a Party was sent to seise their Persons, to Search, and Plunder their Houses; and so after the Infliction of all sorts of Misery and Distress, they are admitted to Liberty, under the Caution of Bonds for Good behaviour, but nothing left to sustain them, or to prevent the Calamitous Assaults of Poverty and Famin.

At another time they proceded with a more Jesuitical Fineness, for having in their Eye a concealed purchase of Mony, or good Movables, in the Hands of a Protestant; immediatly an Order was secretly granted, to seise the Person and secure the Goods: and then to amuse the World with an Opinion of their Justice and Lenity, a Proclamation was conceived with a plausible Promise of Indemnity, to all Protestants under their Protection; and an invitation to all Men, to rest secure under the Benignity of it. But in the mean time the matter is so Ordered, that the Proclamation shall not be published, nor delivered into the Sheriffs Hands, or other Officers, thô Antidated before the Issuing such Order, till a certain Advertisement be received, that the Order is Executed, and the work done.

What a miserable and an inexampled Oppression is it, that the poor Subjects shall be compelled to part with their Goods and Merchandise for a contemptible Lump of Brass, or Pewter! Yet such is, and hath been the constant proceeding of the late King towards his Subjects of Ireland; whose Goods and Commodities he rather seiseth than buyeth, and becoming the grand Merchant of the Kingdom, he is the general ingrosser of all Trade, which he vents and exports to his dear Correspondent in France; Bargaing with the Owner at such a Rate, as the Buyer is pleased to make, and discharging his Contract in
Bits of Copper, Pewter and Brass; which can in no way avail the poor Seller, or support him in the Circulation of his Trade. I will only present the Reader with one Instance, and give him an Authentick account of what Goods were taken up in Dublin at one time for the King's use, (i. e.) were seized by Armed force, and a Price set upon them, at the Pleasure of the taker.

div.p:
This with much more, (about the time Sr. Cloudsly Showell stood before Dublin) was a carrying on Board the Ships that lay in the Harbour, to be transported for France; which for that small time, Sir Cloudsly Showell tarried there, had some Intermission; but as soon as he was gon, the same, and many more Hands were employed, that all might be sent off; whilst the like Methods were a putting in Execution, in all parts of the Country, Seizing and Carrying away, what the Protestants had, in Order to be sent after the former, by the next opportunity: which without doubt has not been neglected, since met with no opposition for several Months thereafter; Beggering the Inhabitants, and Impoverishing the Kingdom, by a wilful Devastation of those Staple Commodities, for which no other return could be expected, (none else being promised) but materials to Murder the remainder of the poor unhappy Protestants
under their Government, and to annoy those that were not; whereas these Commodities at other times, by the Circulation of Trade in these Kingdoms, brought welcome exchanges of Gold and Silver, to the Merchants and other dealers in Ireland; who freely distributed the same among all the other Inhabitants for their benefit, and the advancement of Trade, which being now stopt, and those Commodities sent to strengthen our Enemies; what damage and Loss this has been and may be to England, as well as to the other Dominions, under the Government of their Majesties, Ile not take upon me to Compute.

The Country being well Stored with Grane of all Sorts, especially the Counties about Dublin, whereof the generality of the Inhabitants are Protestants, a very plausible Proclamation was Issued out to encourage the Farmers, to supply and furnish the Markets; which when they had for some time frequented, another Proclamation came forth, setting a precise Rate (but much lower than the Common Market price,) upon all kinds of Grane, Provisions, and other Merchantable Commodities, constraining the Seller to part with his Goods at the Rates prescribed, on pain of losing all without a satisfaction; or inplain English, to Seize on Mens properties and effects under pretence and colour of furnishing the Kings Stores: See the Proclamation, which was first published on a certain Market day, when (by the encouragement the Farmers had from a Proclamation published some short time before, for setting higher Rates on all Commodities,) it was observed the Markets in all parts of the City, had more Corn in them than had been seen for some Months before; the Lord Mayor by name Mac Dermot, some daies before went into the Market, and told the Country People and Farmers, that the reason of the precedent Proclamation was only to supply the King, with what he wanted for his own necessary occasion, and that if they would bring in plenty of Corn, that the King might take off the best, the rest they might sell at the best and greatest prices they could; by which the Markets being very full, the said Lord Mayor with his Officers came into the Market, and Seized all, at what prices he pleased; part whereof he sent to the Kings use, the
rest he disposed as he thought fit, and was highly pleased with the trick; after which there was not seen five Barrels on a Market day.

div.head: By the King a Proclamation.
div.p:
WHereas we are informed, That the Price of Corn, Meal, Wool, Leather, and other Commodities is so high, that the Persons employed by us to make Stores and Magazines of Grain, and to provide Cloaths and other Necessaries for our Troops, cannot Buy the same but at excessive Rates, though we are well assured there are great quantities of all sorts of Grain, Wool, Leather, and other Commodities within this our Kingdom; and having on the one hand considered the absolute necessity of making Magazines and Stores of Grain and Meal for the support of our Army, and of providing Cloaths and other Necessaries for our Troops; And on the other hand, at what Rate the Farmers, Husbandmen, and other Dealers and Traders may sell the same to discharge their Rents, Subsidies, and other Incumbrances, reserving a Competency for the use of their Families, and a sufficient proportion of Seed for Tillage: We have thought fit by the Advice of our Privy Council, to set a Rate upon such Corn, Meal, Wool, Leather, and other Commodities as shall be bought for our use. We do therefore by the Advice aforesaid, strictly Charge and Command all Farmers, Husbandmen, and others, who have any Wheat,
Bear, Barley, Meslin, Oats, or Oatmeal, that they dispose of the same, or so much thereof as we shall think fit to make use of, at the Rates following; That is to say, 20s. the Barrel of the best Wheat, 18s. the Barrel of ordinary Wheat, 15s. the Barrel of Meslin, 12s. the Barrel of the best Bear, 11s. the Barrel of ordinary Bear, 13s. the Barrel of the best Malt, and 12s. the Barrel of ordinary Malt, 14s. the Barrel of good Barley, and 6s. the Barrel of good Oats, in the Counties of Dublin, City of Dublin, Meath, West▪ Meath, Wicklow, and Kildare; and 15s. the Barrel of the best Wheat, 13s. the Barrel of ordinary Wheat, 11s. the Barrel of the best Bear, 10s. the Barrel of Ordinary Bear, 12s. the Barrel of the best Malt, 11s. the Barrel of ordinary Malt, 12s. the Barrel of good Barley, 4s. the Barrel of good Oats, and 12s. the Barrel of good Oatmeal, in all other parts of the Kingdom, the said Barrel to be Bristol Measure, and the said respective Rates to be paid upon the delivery of the said Corn and Meal at our Store next the place where the Corn or Meal lies. And in case the Farmers, Husbandmen, and others that have such Corn or Meal to sell, shall refuse to bring the same to our Stores at the Rates aforesaid, at the Request of the Commissioner-General of our Provisions and Stores, or of our Commissaries of Bread, or his or their Deputies or Agents, We do hereby strictly Charge and Command our respective Lieutenants, Deputy-Lieutenants, and Sheriffs of our Counties of this our Kingdom, that they or any of them do immediately compel the said Farmers, Husbandmen, and others, to Thresh and prepare their said Corn and Meal, and to bring the same to our Stores, or such proportion thereof as shall
be thought necessary for our Service, at the Rates aforesaid; in which Case our said Lieutenants, Deputy-Lieutenants, and Sheriffs, our said Commissioner General of our Provisions and Stores, our Commissaries of Bread, his and their Deputies and Agents are to take special Care, that the said Farmers, Husbandmen and others, having such Corn and Meal be permitted to keep sufficient proportion thereof for the Subsistence of them and their Families, with sufficient quantity of Barley and Oats for Tillage, as aforesaid. And we do further strictly Charge and Command our said Commissioner-General of our Provisions and Stores, our Commissaries of Bread, his or their Deputies or Agents, upon the delivery of any such Corn or Meal into any of our Stores, that they thereupon pay down to the Owners of such Corn and Meal according to the Rates aforesaid. And we do further require our said Commissioner General of our Provisions, to appoint several Store-houses in such Places as may lie convenient for such Farmers, Husbandmen and others, to carry such Corn or Meal to our Stores, as aforesaid. And we do further, by the Advice of our Privy Council, strictly Charge and Command all such as have any store of Wool, Leather, Tallow, or salted Hides, that they dispose of so much thereof for our use, as we shall have occasion for, at the Rates following; That is to say, Good Merchantable Wool 10s. the Stone, (18 lb. to the Stone), and for good Merchantable Tann'd Leather, 7d. the Pound Sole-Leather, and 6d. the Pound Ʋpper Leather; for Tallow, 30s. the Hundred Weight, and for large Ox-Hides salted, 20s. the Hundred Weight; And in case the Owners of such Wool, Leather, Tallow or Hides, shall refuse to supply our Occasions at the
Rates aforesaid, We do hereby declare, That we will give Directions to the Commissioners of our Treasury, to cause so much of the said Wool, Leather, Tallow and Hides to be seized upon for our use at the Rates aforesaid, as we shall have occasion for.

closer.dateline: Given at our Court at Dublin-Castle, the 28th of February, 1689.

div.p: After the Late King was obliged by his necessity to make Brass-Money current in Ireland, it was at first pretended to pass only in Payments between Man and Man in their daily Commerce and Dealings, and in publick payment of Duties to the Exchequer. But soon after the Irish beginning to consider, that they were generally Indebted to the English, and that this might be a fit season, and a lucky opportunity to get their Debts easily and cheaply discharged, a Proclamation was published, enjoyning and requiring, That Copper and Brass-Money should pass as Current Money within the Realm of Ireland, in the payment of Bills, Bonds, Debts by Record, Mortgages, and all other Payments whatsoever. By which Knack many a poor Protestant was Fob'd out of his Right, and compell'd to take an Heap of Trash for his Debt, (as he was for his Wheat and other Commodities) or be precluded from any further satisfaction.

And thus I have heard that Colonel Roger Moore was serv'd, (but I do not aver it upon my certain knowledge) who having an Incumbrance of 3000 l. upon the Lord Dillon's Estate, who is married to the Daughter of the Lord or Lady Tyrconnel; she sent for him, and told him, That having some Money at her command, and being very desirous to take off the burthen from her Daughters Estate, she was content to pay him off in Ready-Money, provided he would make some handsom abatement of the Sum due. The Gentleman being Complaisant to the Lady, and very willing to receive Money in such a time of Scarcity, freely consented to abate a Thousand Pounds, so the rest might
be paid down at once: The Lady seem'd very thankful, and appointed him to come next day, and to bring the Deeds and Obligations with him, and to receive his Money. Accordingly he came, and having given a legal Release, the Lady opened a Door, and shewed him a long Table, covered over with Copper and Brass, and tendered it for his payment: which whether he rejected in Passion, or hired a Cart to carry it away, I cannot tell; but this I can say, having an Estate which was Mortgaged to the old Proprietor, before 1641. to which on Payment of the Mortgage Mony, he hoped to be restored by Repealing the Acts of Settlement; he repaird to me, and desired me, to appoint time and place for Paying the Mortgage Mony, of which I have taken time to consider. One of the most Eminent Silver Smiths in Dublin, having sold all his Plate to a Papist, who promised to pay him his price (agreed upon) in Silver and Gold; but no Faith being to be kept with Hereticks, the Gold-Smith was compeld to take Brass and Copper. But not to detain the Reader with many more of these Examples, I here present you with that Savory and Fruitful Proclamation: Which is, to make Brass Mony pass in Satisfaction of all Debts.

div.head: By the King a Proclamation.
div.p:
WHereas, We have by former Proclamations of the 18th & 27th Days of June last, for the Reasons therein set forth; Ordained and Declared, that a certain Coyn made by our Order of a certain Metal, mixed with Copper and Brass, and Marked and Stamped as in the said Proclamations is expressed in Sixpence,
Twelvepence, and half Crown pieces, should during our Pleasure pass as Current Mony, among all our Subjects within this Realm, according to the Rates and Values in the said Proclamations mention'd; and in all Payments, to be paid either to us or from us, or to, or by any of our Subjects within this Kingdom; excepting Mortgages▪ Bills, Bonds, or Obligations, Debts due by Record, and Mony heretofore left in Trust or keeping with any Person. And whereas it hath been since represented to us, that such restriction upon the said Coyn, is a great hindrance to Trade and Industry, and to the Circulation of the said Mony, in regard Men of Trade and Industry cannot have Credit, without passing Bonds and Judgments, which since they cannot satifie by the said Mony▪ they are therefore the less industrious, to acquire it by the Sale of any of their Goods or Merchandizes, as are also the generality of all others; because when they have acquired any quantity thereof, they cannot thereby pay their Debts, nor clear their Estates from Incumbrances; wherefore We have thought fit by the Advice of our Privy Council, further to Declare and Ordain, that the aforesaid Mony, made of Mixture of Copper and Brass as aforesaid, shall hereafter during our Pleasure pass as Current Mony within this Realm, not only in all Payments, in the said former Proclamations mentioned; but also in all the said Payments of Bills, Bonds, Debts by Record, Mortgages, and all other Payments whatsoever, in the said former Proclamations excepted: And whereas this is Ordered at this time to supply the present scarcity of Mony, and remedy the great inconveniencies which would otherwise ensue; We do therefore hereby Promise and Declare to all our loving Subjects,
that as soon as the said Mony shall be called in, and Decried, We shall thereupon not only receive from all our Loving Subjects within this Kingdom, such proportion thereof, as shall be in any of their Hands, at such time as it shall be so Decried, according to the Value for which it now passes, in satisfaction of any Rents, Customs, Excise, Debts or Duties, which they shall owe to us; but also where no such Debts or Duties shall be due to us, we will make full Satisfaction for the same in Gold, or Silver of the Current Coyn of this Kingdom.

closer.dateline: Given at our Court at Dublin-Castle, the 4th Day of February 1689.

div.p: Of late they are grown so severe to the poor Protestants, that they will not suffer them to buy a loaf of Bread from a Baker, but at the Second hand from the Souldiers, and are forced to pay a treble Rate for it, and even that Liberty is now restrained, since the French are Garisoned in Dublin, so that we may too sadly expect to hear that many of them are Starved in the Streets.

But I challenge all History and Records of Nations, to Parallel the late shameful usage of the poor Protestant Prisoners in Galway, upon whom was placed so Odious a Cheat, so unman-like a Sham, that posterity will hardly be induced to believe it; and I must Implore the Charity of the present Age, not to look upon it as a fable: but it is so certain and so sad a truth, that I defie the Subtilty and Impudence of a Jesuit, to gainsay or contradict it. There was a Stipulation made not long since, between the Late King James and the French Tyrant, to Exchange some Regiments of Auxiliaries, and about Five Thousand Men being accordingly sent from France and Landed in ireland, the Late King James ordered the like
Number of Irish to be forthwith Embarked, and Transported into France, under the Conduct of Major General Mac Carty, (under whom they would do great Feats, as by Experience against the Iniskillin Men,) among whom the Regiment under the Command of Colonel Robert Fielding, alias Hansom Fielding, was appointed to be one; but before he could get his Regiment on Board, a great Number of the Men Run away, according to their natural, and usual custom; so that he became mightily puzled, what Shift to make to Recruit his Regiment, whereupon this Expedient was found out; there was in Gallway about 120 Prisoners, (who had been Seized for endeavouring to make an escape with Sir Thomas Southwell out of the Irish Quarters;) and who had endured the Miseries of Close Imprisonment, Cold, Hunger, and a dayly expectation of a Violent Death for above 14 Months, Lying under Condemnation for Treason: To them Colonel Fielding applied himself, and proposed to them, that for every one of them that would raise eight Men, and deliver them to him, to Recruit his Regiment, such should not only have their immediate Liberty, but an absolute Pardon for all that was past: and to that purpose he produced a Warrant for a General Pardon, which whether it were really the Act of the Late King, or only a Counterfeit Grant, and a Forgery, I cannot take upon me to Determin; But the poor Gentlemen overjoyed with the security of their Lives, and the prospect of their Liberty, consented readily to the Capitulation; and with all earnestness betook themselves to the performance of what was expected on their parts, and in a very short time, about 14 of the Prisoners brought in the Number of Men demanded of them, and delivered them to the Conduct of the Colonel, who carried on the Intrigue without suspicion; but alas the poor unfortunate Gentlemen having Accomplisht their undertaking with extraordinary Pains and Charges, being obliged to pay great Sums of Mony to those Mercenary Men; no sooner was the Colonel with his Men Shipt away, but an Order was sent from the Late King, to Seize upon those deluded Gentlemen, and to recommit them to their former Prison; on pretence that the Contract, made with them by Colonel
Fielding, was not done with his Knowledg or Allowance. The great Turk would Blush to be charged with such an Action, and a very Heathen would abhor it, an Action only fit for the Mounsier of France, and such as are Influenced by his Example.

And now let me give you a Tast of the hopeful Fruits of an Arbitrary, unlimited and Dispensing Power, which the Late King claimed in Scotland, aim'd at in England, and hath been effectually exercized in Ireland: where (by his absolute Authority to be obeyed without reserve), he hath upon the great emergency of the occasion, caused a heavy Tax to be Levied of his Subjects, by the naked Authority of a Proclamation, without the preliminary sanction of an Act of Parliament. And this that follows next is the very Tenor of it.

div.head: By the King a Proclamation.

closer.dateline: Given at our Court at Dublin Castle, the 4th day of February, 1689.

div.p: As for Ship-Mony, and other heavy Burdens laid on the Subjects in the Reign of King CHARLES the First, there was some colour of Law, and many Precedents produced to favour, if not to Warrant such Imposition; yet that was condemned by publick Acts of Parliament, and Judgments in the Kings Courts in Westminster. But at this time of Day, after all those Proceedings, for a King and his Privy Council, to impose and levy a Tax of Twenty Thousand Pounds per Mensem upon the Personal Estates, and the benefit of Trade, is a Strain of Arbitrary Power, never before put in practice, except by Richard the Second; and what calamitous Effects that produced, and how Fatal to himself, the Histories of that Time do sufficiently testifie.

Such Proceedings as these, tho' never so Arbitrary and Illegal, may yet receive some extenuation and excuse from the pressing Streights and irresistible exigency of Affairs; but for a King eagerly, wilfully, and considerately to break his Word, and violate his Solemn Promises, made, and often reiterated to his People, (as he called them) for the entire Maintenance and exact observance of the Act of Settlement in Ireland, is so dishonourable an Instance of Injustice, as is not to be reconciled with the ordinary methods of Morality: And if the Reader will give himself the trouble to look over the Act, lately made in The Mock Parliament in Ireland, (Entituled, An Act for the Repealing the Acts of Settlement and Explanation, &c.) which he may find in the Book lately set forth, giving a List of the Persons lately Attainted in the Parliament there, pag. 51. which would be too tedious to recite here at large; he will be convinced, how little or no encouragement there is for Protestants to expect any security under a Popish King, who cannot only at his pleasure dispense with the established Laws of the Land, but can procure a Dispensation from a Power (to which he has blindly made himself subordinate) for the Iniquity of such irregular Actions.

And since we see that he came by the Power of a French Army, to Reassume what he had Abdicated, only to subject us to the Tyranny of France and their Dragoons; what Inducement have we Hereticks (as they call us,) (with whom no person of his Perswasion is to keep Faith) to hope, much less to believe, that he will keep or perform any Promise for the benefit of a Protestant, having in so many almost innumerable Instances, before his Deserting the People of England, Violated every Individual part of that Solemn Oath taken at his Coronation?

But as if all that hath been before observed, were slight and trivial Matters, and not of force sufficient to undeceive the grumbling Generation of Men, let every wavering and unsatisfied Person, duly and without Prejudice weigh and consider the Act of Attainder, lately past in Ireland, wherein he shall observe, not only the utmost Severity, Partiality, and Injustice done to the Protestants, but manag'd in so fallacious a manner, that the whole Proceeding is complicated with Fraud, Trepanning and Circumvention. For the secret Machinations of the Papists, and the open and uncontroll'd Outrages done by them on the Persons, Estates, and Goods of the Protestants, are too notorious, and may justly excuse them before God and Man, and warrant their voluntary withdrawing themselves from under the Tyranny of their implacable Enemies and Oppressors; yet the Process against them hath been managed with so much Art, Fallacy, and Surprize, that it is morally impossible for any Protestant to avoid the Forfeiture of Life and Estate. Indeed no other Quarter or Usage could rationally be expected from a Parliament, wherein its to be noted, that Nine parts of Ten were the Macs, O's, and Clans: In a word, The Offspring of those Vulturs, who for their Rebellion and horrid Treason in 1641, justly forfeited all they could pretend to; and at the Sitting of this Parliament were not worth one Groat, but what they had since August 1688, plunder'd and taken from the Protestants. For conceiving that the Kingdom was their own, and that they had received the accomplishment of their Expectations and Attempts for several Ages past, The total extirpation
of the British Names and Blood; they began to exert all the Articles which inveterate Malice, (whetted with an inreconcilable Aversion to the Reformed Religion) could suggest And First, for such as either had not a convenient opportunity to escape, or were resolutely determin'd to abide the Brunt, and continue under their Protection, they found this Expedient to promote, and ascertain their Destruction; They Issued out Warrants to the Sheriffs of the respective Counties, where the Estates of the Protestants lay, while their Persons were under their Power, and in their sight in Dublin; and so proceeding by way of secret Outlawries, they brought them under the Attainder, confiscated their Personal Estates, and Seized the Real, delivering over the Possession to the old Proprietors, or whom else they pleased. It were easie to demonstrate this in the case of several Persons, as—

And as for those whom they term Absentees, they have dealt with them most disingenuously (to say no worse of it) and handled them as Exiles, and proscribed Persons; for having collected a Schedule of their Names, they foisted them into a Proclamation, limiting their return to certain fixt days; some in September, some in October, some in November; but in the mean time they took especial Care, that no Noise should be made of it, and lest the sound of such a Warning-Piece should reach into England, Scotland or the Isle of Man; They provided so, that no such Proclamation should be made publick, till the several days of Grace were Elapsed; And then by virtue of the Act against Absentees, they presently Seized on all the Personal Estates of such Persons, and confiscated them to the use of the late King. I shall trouble the Reader only with the Preamble, and a few of the first Lines in it, being Entituled, An Act for Forfeiting and Vesting in his Majesty the Goods of Absentees.

div.head: Here follows the Act of Attainder, Past in the Parliament Assembled in Dublin by the Late King James in May 1689; by which Act, and the most disingenuous Proceedings of that Parliament and the Late King, Destruction is thunder'd against Thousands of all Degrees and Qualities of Men, Women and Infants.
An Act for Forfeiting, and Vesting in his Majesty, the Goods of Absentees.
div.p: WHereas upon the General Defection of your Majesties Subjects in England, several of your Majesties Subjects have Deserted this Kingdom, and repaired into your Majesties Kingdom of England, and elsewhere; thereby Endeavouring to weaken your Majesties Interest here, and shewing an Apparent diffidence of your Majesties Protection; most of which Persons have Actually taken Arms, under the unnatural Usurper in England; and divers others of your Majesties Subjects became Rebels and Traytors within this your Realm: And forasmuch, as the said Persons have left behind them several Goods and Chattels, and personal Estates, part whereof hath been Seized in your Majesties Name, or otherwise by several Persons, who have not yet answered, or accounted for the same to your Majesty.

Be it therefore Enacted by the Kings most Excellent Majesty, with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons in this present Parliament Assembled, and by the Authority of the same, that all Goods and Chattels, Corn in Ground, Debts by Judgments, Statutes, Bonds, Bills, Books or otherwise; and all Arrears of Rent, belonging to any Person or Persons, in Rebellion against your Majesty, out of this your Majesties Kingdom; or belonging to any Person or Persons, that by any Act of this present Parliament, shall be Adjudged and Declared a forfeiting Person, or Persons Absent, and all other Persons Absent out of this Realm, and that Aid, Abet or Assist the said Prince of Orange, Minors under the Age of Seventeen years; and such Person or Persons, who are Intituled to such Goods or Chattels, or Debts, as aforesaid in trust for others, who are not Absent, or Joyned with the Rebels; and such Person or Persons, as for some Reasonable cause to be allowed of, and approved under the Hands of the Commissioners of your Majesties Revenue in this Kingdom, or the major part of them; within three Months after the Royal Assent given to this Act, always Excepted and Foreprized, shall from the Fifth day of November last, be, and hereby are vested in, and setled in your Majesty, your Heirs and Successors, and that all Person and Persons, who since the said Fifth day of November last, have Seized or possessed themselves of any Goods or Chattels belonging, or pretended to belong to any Person or Persons, upon pretence of such Person or Persons being in Rebellion, or Absent out of this your Majesties Realm: And all Persons, who since the First day of May last, have received any Arrears of Rent or Debts, due to any Person or Persons, who are or have been in Rebellion, or now are Absent out of your Majesties Kingdom, Be and are hereby Declared to be Debtors and Accountants to your Majesty, your Heirs and Successors; and such Person and Persons, shall by Process out of your Majesties Court of Exchequer, to be (Issued within two Years and no longer,) be made chargeable and liable as in other Debts, &c.

[This last part is for their own benefit, otherwise they might
have spared the trouble they took in framing the Act; for in March, April and May, before their Parliament Sate, Persons appointed, and same without any Authority came to Absentees, nay, to some wherein the Protestants remain'd, and under the Pretence of Absentees Goods, or Searching for Arms, they carried away what Goods they pleased; and the Commissioners sent for the Agents and Servants of the Absentees, administring what Interrogatories they pleased; and if the Servants refused or could not discover any thing, they were Committed; As for Instance, One Mr. Smith, who (tho he was a Roman Catholick, yet) out of a Spark of Gratitude, and a Principle of Honesty, and Integrity to his Trust; would not discover his Master the Duke of Ormonds Writings and Rentals, or deliver them, whereupon he was confined for a considerable time. [See in the Margin of the Book, wherein this Act of Parliament is much to the same effect, Fol. 41]
In the next place, I shall Recite the Clauses in the Act of Attainder, relating to the Absentees, and then offer some plain obvious Remarks upon them.

And First, The Scene opens Tragically, and Thunders Destruction to some Hundreds of Lords, Baronets and Knights, together with some Thousands of Gentlemen, and others in these words; Be in Enacted by your most Excellent Majesty, by and with the Advice and Consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons in this present Parliament Assembled, and by Authority of the same, That the Persons hereafter Named, being Persons who have Notoriously joyned in the said Rebellion and Invasion; and some of which are upon Indictment Condemned, some Executed for High Treason, and the rest Run away or Abscond, or are now in the Actual Service of the Prince of Orange against your Majesty, and others killed in open Rebellion, viz.

Francis March Lord Archbishop of Dublin, James Butler Duke of Ormond, Richard Boyl Earl of Cork; and then after enumerating some Thousands of Names, (the Act goes on and says:) whether Dead or Alive, or Killed in open Rebellion, or now in Arms against your Majesty, or otherwise; and
every of them shall be deem'd, taken, reputed, and are hereby Declared and Adjudged Traytors, Convicted and Attainted of High Treason; and shall suffer such pains of Death, Penalties and Forfeitures, respectively, as in Cases of High Treason are accustomed; Provided that in case it happen, that any of the Persons hereby Attainted, or to be Attainted, do now abide or dwell in this Kingdom, and are ameanable to the Law, that then and in such case, if such Person and Persons, do by the Tenth day of August, 1689. without compulsion, of his own accord, come in and deliver himself▪ to the Lord Chief Justice of his Majesties Court of Kings Bench in Ireland, or to any other of the Judges of the said Court, or any other of your Majesties four Courts in Dublin; or to any Judge of Assize in their Circuits, to be charged with any Treason, to be Imputed to him or them, That then and in such Case such Person and Persons, if after acquitted by the Law of this Land, or discharged by Proclamation, shall be freed, discharged and accquitted from all pains punishments and forfeitures by this Act incurred, laid or imposed. Any thing in this Act to the Contrary in any wise notwithstanding in any wise notwithstanding.
Secondly, A multitude of names are Mustered up as Absentees, and their Doom runs thus,

And whereas the several Persons hereafter named, viz. John Veasy Lord Archbishop of Tuam, Arthur Chichester Earl of Donnegall, Falliot Wingfield Viscount Powerscourt, William Morton Lord Bishop of Killdare, with some Hundreds more, as in the former Printed Book of the Names, from page 24 to page 30, (and says) have Absconded themselves from this Kingdom, and have gon into England, or some other places beyond the Seas since the Fifth day of November last, or in some short time before, and did not return, although called home by Their Majesties Gracious Proclamation; which absconding, and not returning, cannot be construed otherwise than a wicked and Traiterous purpose, and may thereby justly forfeit all their Right and Pretensions to all and every the Lands▪ Tenements and Hereditaments to them belonging in this Kingdom.

Be it therefore Enacted by the Authority aforesaid, That in case the said person and persons do not by the first Day of September, 1689. of his or their own accord, without compulsion, return into this Kingdom, and tender him and themselves to the Chief Justice of his Majesty's Court of Kings Bench, or to some other Judge of the said Court, or Judge of Assizes in the Circuit, or any of the Lords of your Majesties most Honourable Privy Council, to be charged with any Crimes to him or them to be imputed, (that then) or in case he or they, upon his or their Return, shall be Convict by Verdict of Twelve Men, or by his or their own Confession, upon his or their Arraignment for Treason, or upon his or their Arraignment stand Mute; such person and persons so absent, and not returning as aforesaid, or after his or their Return, being Convict of Treason, as aforesaid, shall from and after the said First day of September, 1689, be deemed, reputed and taken as Traytors convict and attainted of High Treason, and shall suffer such pains of Death, and other Forfeitures and Penalties, as in cases of High Treason are accustomed: But in case such person and persons so Returning, be upon such his or their Tryal Acquitted or Discharged by Proclamation, then such person and persons respectively, shall from thenceforth be freed, discharged, and acquitted from all Pains, Punishments, and Forfeitures, by this Act incurred, laid, or imposed; Any thing in this Act to the contrary notwithstanding.
[This Sentence being past against the Absentees,]
Thirdly, A multitude of Names [as in the former printed List of Names, pag. 31.] are muster'd up as Absentees, and their Doom runs thus:

And whereas the several persons hereafter named, viz. Robert▪ Ridgway Earl of Londonderry, Arthur Loftis Viscount Loftis of Eli, with about 500 more, before the Fifth Day of November last, absented themselves from this Kingdom, and
live in England, Scotland, or the Isle of Man, and there now abide, and by not coming or returning into this Kingdom upon your Majesties Proclamation, to assist in Defence of this Realm according to their Allegiance, must be presumed to adhere to the said Prince of Orange, in case they return not within the time in this Act prescribed, and thereby may justly forfeit all the Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, which they or any of them are entituled unto within this Kingdom.

Be it therefore Enacted by the Authority aforesaid, That in case the said person and persons last mentioned, do by the first day of October 1689. of his and their own accord, without compulsion, Return into this Kingdom, and tender him and themselves to the Chief Justice of your Majesties Court of Kings Bench, or to some other Judge of the said Court or Judge of Assize in his Circuit, or to any of the Lords of your Majesties most Honourable Privy Council, To be charged with any Crime or Crimes, to him or them to be charged or imputed, that then, in case that he or they upon such his or their Return shall be convict by Verdict of Twelve Men, or by his own Confession upon his or their Arraignment for Treason, or upon his or their Arraignment stand Mute; such person and persons so Absent, and not Returning as aforesaid, or after his or their Return, being convict of Treason, as aforesaid, shall from and after the said First day of October 1689. be deemed, reputed, and taken as Traytors Convict, and Attainted of High Treason, and shall suffer such Pains of Death, and other Forfeitures and Penalties, as in Cases of High Treason is accustomed: But in case such person and persons respectively shall return, they shall from thenceforth be freed, discharged and acquitted from all Pains, Punishments, and Forfeitures by this Act incurr'd, laid, or imposed; any thing in this Act to the contrary notwithstanding.

Which terrible Clause in the Act seems to be sweetned
by a most gracious Proviso extended to a select number of Persons which goes on in these Words: Provided always, That in case your Majesty shall happen to go into the Kingdom of England or Scotland before the said first day of October 1689. Then if the said Sir William Meredith, Sir Charles Chiney, Sir Charles Loyd, Sir Algernoon Mayo, Sir Joseph Williamson, Sir William Parker, Alexander Frazier Esq; John Hollum, Daniel of the Iron-works, Brook Bridges, Charles Vaughan, Hugh Merick, Nathaniel Huet, Heirom Hawkins, Major John Read, William Trenchard, J—Trenchard his Eldest Son, Erasmus Smith, Harison of Balvarneen, Achilles Daniel, John Lovet, John Castle, Joseph Rutterton, Thomas Valentine Clark of Ballyturmey, John Cright, George Clarke of Shaccrelin, Thomas Chinucks, William Warmsby, Richard Cluterbuck, Erasmus Smith, William Wats, John Evelin, Thapcote of Loughkent, Page of the same▪ Thomas Moor, Humphry Wray, Edward Crafton, Alderman Clarke, John Clarke, Arthur Aneste, William Warwick, Purefy Warwick▪ Captain Coaps, Robert Boye of Kilgrant, Hugh Ratclif, Edward Nelthrop, Robert Dixon, Samuel Clarke, John Jones, Henry Payne, George Clark and Gilbert Thacker, whose Dwellings and Residence always hath been in England,
See in the former printed List of the Names, pag. 30 & 31. has more names than ought to be in that Clause and therefore not true. shall give your Majesty such Testimony of their Loyalty, and Fidelity as that your Majesty will be pleased on or before the said first day of October, 1689. to certifie under your Privy Signet or Sign Manual unto the chief Governor or Governors of this Kingdom, that your Majesty is satisfied and assured of the Loyalty and Fidelity of the Persons last before named, or of any of them; that then, if such Certificate shall on or before the First day of November 1689, be produced to the chief Governor or Governors of this Kingdom, and Enrolled▪ in your Majesties High Court of Chancery, the same shall be a sufficient Discharge and Acquittal to such of the Persons last before
named, and every of them respectively, whose Loyalty and Fidelity your Majesty will be pleased to certify in manner as aforesaid.

And be it further Enacted, That in the mean time, and until such Return and Acquittal, all the Lands Tenements and Hereditaments within this Kingdom belonging to all and every Absentee and Absentees, or other Person to be attainted as aforesaid, shall be, and are hereby vested in your Majesty, your Heirs and Successors, as from the first day of August last past.

Then comes the Stabbing Clause, with a Face like Janus, Looking forward and backward both at once, in this tenor. And be it further Enacted by the Authority aforesaid, that all and every such Person and Persons, as by any the foregoing Clauses is, are or shall be respectively attainted, shall be from the first day of August, One Thousand, Six Hundred Eighty and Eight, forfeit unto your Majesty, your Heirs and Successors, all such Mannors, Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments, all Right, Title, Service, Chiefry, Ʋse, Trust, Condition, Fee, Rent Charge, Right of Redemption of Mortgages, Right of Entries, Right of action, or any other Interest of what nature or Kind soever, either in Law or Equity, of, in or into any Lands, Tenements or Hereditaments, within this Kingdom, belonging or appertaining to such Person or Persons, so as aforesaid attainted, or to be attainted in his or their own Right, or to any other Interest for him or them on the said first day of August, 1689, or at any time since; and all the said Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, so as aforesaid forfeited unto, and vested in your Majesty, your Heirs and Successors, hereby, are and shall be vested in your Majesty, your Heirs and Successors, whether such Person or Persons were seized thereof in Fee Absolute or Conditional, or in Tail, or for Life or Lives, and that freed and freely discharged, of and from all Estates Tail, and for Life; and from all Reversions and Remainders for Life, for Years,
or in Fee Absolute or Conditional, or in Tail for any Person or Persons whatsoever, such Remainders, as by one Act or Statute of this present Parliament, Entituled, An Act for Repealing the Act of Settlement and Explanation, Resolution of the Doubts, and all Grants, Patents and Certificates pursuant to them, or any of them, or by this present Act, are saved and preserved, always excepted and foreprized: Provided always, that any Remissness or Forfeiture of any Tenant in Dower, Tenant by the Curtesie, Jointress for Life, or other Tenant for Life or Lives in actual Possession, shall not extend to bar, forfeit, make void or discharge any Reversion vested in any Person or Persons not ingaged in the Usurpation or Rebellion aforesaid, such Reversion and Reversions being immediately depending or expectant upon the particular Estate of such Tenant in Dower, Tenant by the Courtesie, Joyntress for Life, or other Tenant for Life or Lives, any thing in the said Act of Repeal, or in this present Act to the contrary notwithstanding. Provided always, and be it further Enacted by the Authority aforesaid, that nothing in this present Act contained, shall any way extend to be construed, to extend to forfeit or vest in your Majesty, your Heirs or Successors any Remainder or Remainders for valuable consideration limited or setled by any settlement or conveyance made for such valuable consideration, either of Marriage or Marriage Portion, or other valuable consideration whatsoever, upon any Estate for Life or Lives, to any Person or Persons not concerned in the Usurpation or Rebellion aforesaid, such Remainder or Remainders, as are limited or setled by any conveyance wherein there is any power for revoking and altering all or any the use or uses therein limited; and also such Remainder and Remainders as are limited upon any Settlement or Conveyance of any Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments commonly called Plantation Lands; and all Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments,
held or enjoyed under such Grants from the Crown, or Grants upon the Commission, or Commissions of Grace, for remedy of defective Titles, either in the Reign of King James the First, or King Charles the First, in which several Grants respectively, there are Provisoes or Covenants for raising or keeping any number of Men or Arms for the King's Majesty against Rebels or Enemies, or for raising of Men for his Majesties Service, for expedition of War, always excepted, and foreprised, all which Remainders limited by such conveyances wherein there is a power of Revocation for so much of the Lands, Uses and Estates therein limited, as the said power doth or shall Extend unto; and all such Remainders as are derived or limited, from or under such Interest made of such Plantation Lands, or other Lands held as aforesaid, under such Grants from the Crown, and all and every other Remainder and Remainders, Reversion and Reversions, not herein mentioned to be saved and preserved, shall by Authority of this present Parliament be deemed, construed and adjudged void, debarred and discharged to all intents and purposes whatsoever against your Majesty, your Heirs and Successors, and yours and their Grantees or Assigns, and the said Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments belonging to such Rebels as aforesaid, shall be vested in your Majesty, your Heirs and Successors freed and discharged from the said Remainder and Remainders saved and preserved by this Act, and that it may appear with all convenient speed.

Be it Enacted by the Authority aforesaid, That the respective Persons Intituled to such Remainders and Reversions, do within Sixty days next after the first sitting of the Commissioners for Examining the said Act of Repeal, and this present Act, exhibit their Claims before the said Commissioners, and make out their Titles to such Remainder or Remainders, so as to procure their Adjudication, and Certificate for the same, or the Adjudication or Certificate of some Three or more of them; and
further, that all Remainders for which such Adjudication and Certificate shall not be procured at or before One Hundred and Twenty days after the first sitting of the said Commissioners, shall be void, and for ever Barred or Excluded; any thing in this Act, or other matter to the contrary in any wise notwithstanding. All which Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments, mentioned as aforesaid, to be forfeited unto, and vested in your Majesty by any the Clauses aforesaid, and are hereby declared to be so forfeited unto, and vested in your Majesty, without any▪ Office or Inquisition thereof found or to be found, and the same to be to the Uses, Intents and Purposes, as in the said Act of Repeal, and in this present Act mentioned and expressed.

The Fifth is a wheedling Clause to amuse a certain small number of Women, Widows, Minors and Sick-Persons with a seeming Latitude to return: but their Estates are sure to be vested in the King till they do, as more at large you may see, viz.

And whereas the several Persons hereafter named, viz. Lyonel Earl of Orrery▪ Mrs. Traps, Anne Vicountess Dowager of Dungannon, Robert Boyl Esquire, Katherine Woodcock, Alice Countess Dowager of Drogheda, and the rest, as in the former Book of the Persons attainted. p. 37, 38, to about the number of Eighty Persons, are and for some time past, have been absent out of this Kingdom, and by reason of Sickness, Nonage, Infirmities, and other disabilities, may for some time further be obliged so to stay out of this Kingdom, or be disabled to return thereunto. Nevertheless, it being much to the weakenning of this Realm, that any of the Rents or Profits of the Lands, Tenements or Hereditaments therein, should be sent into or spent in any other Place beyond the Seas, but that the same should be Kept and Employed within the Realm for the better support and defence thereof; Be it therefore Enacted by the Authority aforesaid, that all the Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments,
Use, Trust, Possession, Reversion, Remainder, and all and every other Estate, Title and Interest whatsoever belonging or appertaining to all and every the Persons herein before last mentioned within this Kingdom, be and are hereby vested in your Majesty, your Heirs and Successors. Provided always, that if any Person or Persons in the next foregoing Clause mentioned, have hitherto behaved themselves Loyally and Faithfully to your Majesty, that then, if they or any of them, their or any of their Heirs do hereafter return into this Kingdom, and behave him, or themselves as becometh Loyal Subjects, and do on or before the Last day of the first Term next ensuing, after such their return, Exhibit his or their Petition or Claim, before the Commissioners for Executing the said Acts, (if then sitting,) or in his Majesties high Court of Chancery, or in his Majesties Court of Exchequer for any such Lands, Tenements or Hereditaments, and make out his or their Title thereunto, and obtain the Adjudication and Decree of any of the said Courts of and for such his or their Title, that then and in such case, such Adjudication and Decree shall be sufficient to all such Person and Persons, for devesting and restoring such Estate, and no other as shall be therein and thereby to him or them adjudged and decreed; and that the order of any of the said Courts shall be sufficient Warrant to all Sheriffs, or other proper Officer to whom the same shall be directed, to put such Person or Persons in the actual Seizing and Possession of the said Land, any thing in this Act contained, or any other Statute, Law or Custom whatsoever to the contrary in any wise notwithstanding. Provided always, and be it further Enacted by the Authority aforesaid, that neither the said Act of Repeal, or this present Act, or any thing in them or either of them contained shall extend to, or be construed to forfeit or vest in your Majesty, your Heirs or Successors, or otherwise to Barr, Extinguish or Weaken, any right of Entry,
right of Action, Use, Trust, Lease, Condition or Equity of Redemption, of any Mortgage or Mortgages, which on the first day of August, 1688, belonged or appertained to any Person or Persons not being forfeiting Persons within the true Intent and Meaning of the said Act of Repeal, or this present Act, and which ever since the first day of August, 1688, continued or remained in such Persons, not being Persons, or descended or devolved, or come from them, or any of them, to any of their Heirs, Executors or Administrators, not being forfeiting Persons as aforesaid, any thing in this or the said Act of Repeal to the contrary notwithstanding. Provided always, that the Person or Persons claiming such right of Entry, right of Action, Use, Trust, Lease, Condition or Equity of Redemption, of Mortgage, do and shall Exhibit his and their claim for the same, before the Commissioners for Execution of the said Act of Repeal, or of this present Act within Sixty days after the first sitting of the said Commissioners, and procure the Adjudication of them, or any three or more of them thereupon, within one Hundred and Twenty days after the said first sitting of the said Commissioners.

And whereas, by one or more Office or Offices in the time of the Earl of Strafford's Government, in the Reign of King Charles the First of ever Blessed Memory, all or a great part of the Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments in the Province of Connaught, and Counties of Clare, Limerick and Tiperary, were vested in his Majesty, and by the Acts of Settlement or Explanation, the said Office and Offices are declared to be null and void; since which time, the said Acts have been by the said Acts of Repeal Repealed, and thereby some prejudice might arise or accrew to the Proprietors concerned in them Lands, if not prevented. Be it therefore Enacted, by the Authority aforesaid, that the said Office and Offices, and every of them, commonly called the Grand
Office, and the Title thereby found or endeavoured to be made out, or set up from the time of finding or taking thereof, was and is hereby declared to be null and void to all intents and purposes whatsoever: Provided always that nothing herein contained, shall any way extend to charge any Person or Persons who hath bona fide paid any Rent, or Arrears of Rent, that has been due and payable out of any Lands hereby vested in your Majesty; or to charge any Steward or Receiver that Received any such Rents or Arrears of Rent, if he bona fide paid the same; but that he and they shall be hereby discharged for so much as he or they so bona fide paid against your Majesty, your Heirs and Successors. Provided always, and it is hereby Enacted, that every Person not being a forefeiting Person, within the true intent and meaning of the said former Act, or of this present Act, and who before the Seventh day of May, 1689, had any Statute Staple, or Recognizance for payment of Money, or any Mortgage, Rent Charge, Portion, Trust, or other Incumbrance either in Law or Equity; or any Judgement before the Two and Twentieth day of May, 1689, for payment of Mony which might charge any of the Estates, Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments so as aforesaid forfeited unto, and vested in your Majesty, shall and may have the benefit of the said Statutes Staple Judgments, Recognizances, Mortgages, Rents Charges, Portions, Trusts, and other Incumbrances out of the Estate or Estates, which would be liable thereunto, in case the said former Act or this present Act had never been made. Provided always, that the Person and Persons who had such Statutes Staple, Judgments, Recognizances or other Trusts or Incumbrances, do claim the same before the Commissioners, for Execution of the said former Act within two Months after the first sitting of the said Commissioners, and procure their Adjudication thereof, within such reasonable time as the said Commissioners shall appoint for determining
the same. And to the end that such Person and Persons as shall have any of the said Lands, Tenements, or Hereditaments so to be granted unto him above all Incumbrances, and may injoy the same against all Statutes Staple, Judgments, Recognizances, Mortgages, Rents Charge, and other Incumbrances, not claimed and adjudged as aforesaid. Be it therefore further Enacted by the Authority aforesaid, that all such Lands, Tenements, and Hereditaments as shall be forfeited unto, and vested in your Majesty, and granted by Letters Patents pursuant to the said former Act, or this present, shall be, and are hereby freed and acquitted and discharged of and from all Estates, Charges and Incumbrances whatsoever, other than what shall be claimed and adjudged as aforesaid.

Upon the First I do observe, that after they are all marked with a black Coal, and actually attainted of Treason whether Dead or Alive, Killed in open Rebellion, or in Arms, or otherwise; (i. e.) wheresoever they are, or whatsoever they are doing, there is a very merciful saving extended to them under these favourable conditions: First, They must be commorant and resident in the Kingdom. Secondly, That they must be ameanable to Law. Thirdly, That they must by the Tenth day of August, 1689, surrender themselves to Justice. Fourthly, That they shall be discharged by Proclamation, if they shall be acquitted upon their Tryal; while all this is nothing but palpable Collusion and Banter, they very well knowing, that such as had taken Arms, were either out of the Kingdom, or resident in the Protestant Quarters, that it was impossible, for them, or the greatest part of them, to make their appearance by the tenth of August 1689. That no Man who had not forfeited Reason and common Sense, would come in with a Halter about his Neck, and try whether they could find a Hangman; or being subject to the pains of High-treason, to
make an experiment of the Justice of Popish Judges, and the Mercy of a Popish Jury.

By the second Clause relating to the Abscondees, A time is aflowed them to the first of September 1689. to return and appear: But upon what Conditions? (why) only that they shall of their own accord render themselves to Justice, and then, if by the Verdict of twelve Men they shall he Convicted of Treason (which beyond all doubt or question would be the Fate of every one of them,) they are to be decently, and legally Beheaded or Hang'd: and if any of them shall upon his Tryal be acquitted or discharged, then to be freed from all Penalties and Forfeitures, which indeed, in good reason ought so to be, but so much Indifferency and Candor is not to be expected from Cannibals. And for my part I would as soon believe Transubstantiation, or trust to be saved by the Supererogation of other Mens Merits.

The third, which seems to have an aspect only on such as are denominated Absentees, is as full fraught with Tricks and Designs, as it abounds with Mischief and Malice; for to say nothing of that great number of Gentlemen, Merchants and Tradesmen, who for the necessary preservation of their Lives, have been constrain'd to abfent themselves, and seek a Shelter in England, Scotland, and the Isle of Man; there are many of the Nobility and Gentry of and in England, who are exposed to the reach of this fatal Summons, who never were commorant in Ireland, never saw the Country, and possibly never intended to see it, yet they are obliged under pain of High Treason, and Forfeiture of Lives and Estates, to appear there by the first of October 1689. and to render themselves to some Magistrate, and submit to a Tryal for such Crimes as it pleases their Enemies to suggest, and their Prosecutors to urge. Many others of them have been absent, and setled in England for divers Years, some for above twenty; yet it is expected that they must now take upon them a Winter Journy, and
patiently submit to be hang'd for presuming to cross the Seas, when there might be after an unforeseen occasion to employ their Service; but it hath so fallen out, that neither the one nor the other hath been terrified by these Threats which they never heard of till long after the day of Grace was expired, but have rather adventured to run the Risque, and be devested of their Estates for a while, no way doubting of a Recovery and Restitution in good time. Against this terrible Storm there is but one Anchor to trust to; and that to be rely'd on only by a select number, and that is to give such Testimony of their Loyalty and Fidelity to King James, in case he shall happen to go into England or Scotland before the first day of October 1689. as that upon a Certificate from him, and the Inrolment of it in Chancery before the first day of November 1689. they may be white Boys again: But forasmuch as the late King hath not thought it fit to come upon the Place, and make his demand, I conceive them absolved from all breach of Duty, tho at the same time they have slipt all other Opportunites of purchasing their Pardon.

The fourth enacting Clause is so Comprehensive, so armed at all Points against all manner of Excuses, Subterfuges and Evasions, that whosoever shall flatter himself with a hope of Security in that Harbour, will certainly split upon a Rock; He that shall wade in that Tempestuous Sea, shall never be able to stem the Tide: For in a Word, All sorts of Estates, Rights and Properties belonging to all sorts of Men, except the Rebellious and Bloody Irish, and such unhappy Persons as have been bewitched into a Confederacy with them, are doom'd to an irreversible Forfeiture, and vested in the late King, and that Title thereunto, to commence from the first of August 1688. when all Things were quiet, in alta Pace, and many Months were past after that day, before there was the least umbrage given of any Opposition, or Defection, but then to clap in an useless Proviso, whereby
all Persons claiming any Reversions or Remainders, are stinted to exhibite them within sixty days after the first sitting of their new fangled Commissioners, and to procure an Adjudication or Certificate from them within one hundred and twenty days after the first sitting, is a Rule so Repugnant to Reason, Law and Equity, that it evidently appears to be contrived on purpose to jeer and ridicule the poor Sufferers; For could it be imagined that any Protestants would adventure to go among them during the Flames of a raging War, to make a demand of a present or future Title, and stay there if they might be suffered, till that very precious Court for Adjudication of Claims should fit, and be established? but the burden of the Song is; let all be vested in his Majesty. And thus, whether they be attainted as Absentees, or found guilty upon the Tryal, or rejected in their Claims before the Commissioners, all is summoned up in one and the same Conclusion, the whole Estates of the Protestants Real and Personal, must be forfeited, and the King must have them towards a Reprisal of what he abdicated in England.

The same Spirit and Humor runs in the fifth declarative and enacting Clause, pretending a Shadow of Favour to certain Persons therein named by reason of Minority, Widowhood, or Sickness, but canting in the same strain with the former Clause and Proviso's, so that all Sexes and Degrees, according to their Design and Contrivance, are irrecoverably barred from all Possession, Right, Remainder or Reversion, so long as they can be prosperous in this Holy War, which is apparently grounded upon a National, as well as a Religious Quarrel.

I am very unwilling to imploy the Reader with a nauseous Repetition of any Matter couched in the precedent Observations, which cannot be avoided if I should go about to make a direct Answer to the Absurdities in each single Paragraph, of that famous Act of Attainder whereby the Irish have fully and apparently demonscrated
to the world, that as English Men, they look upon us as Intruders; as Protestants, they treat us as Miscreants and Hereticks. And since neither the horrible Murder perpetrated in the last Rebellion, nor the present burning of Houses, destruction of Plantations, general depopulation of the Country, are like to be available to extinguish the Families, and subvert the Religion; They have now tryed their utmost effort, by Seizing and Confiscating all Personal Estates, and by the absolute alienation of all their Rights, Titles, and Interests, so that from henceforth it was intended that no English Protestant must dare to set his Foot in Ireland, nor his Children call to mind that ever any of his Forefathers had a footing there.
