Nevertheless upon the review of the remaining part of the Act of Attainder, it will not be amiss to offer a Diversion to the Reader, by making some brief Remarks on the injustice, subtilty and partiality comprehended in it. For Men after they are actually attainted, are invited to appear and shew cause why they should not be Executed; their Appearance is limited to certain days and times. And lest any inconsiderate Man should be so Fool-hardy, as to adventure on his Purgation, there is no publick notice given of the Appearance required, till the days are Incurred and past; they are obliged to put in Claims, and to solicite an Adjudication before certain partial and prejudicated Commissioners, who are to meet, none knows when; and will determine none knows what: Nay, in some cases, they are positively appointed to put in their claim within Two Months after the first sitting of such Commissioners, and afterwards to procure their Adjudication within such Reasonable time, as the Commissioners shall appoint for determining the same.

And because a private Act past in the Reign of King Charles the Second, in favour of the Renowned Duke of Albemarle, whereby several Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments, are conveyed to him, in testimony of the greatest and most
important service that ever was performed by a Subject, yet because the ancient Proprietors of the said Lands, (i. e.) those notorious Rebels, and Murderers, who justly forfeited for their Treason, are thereby barred and deprived of their ancient Estates, that Act must be repealed, and the ancient Proprietors restored; which is a high piece of Ingratitude to the memory of that Illustrious Person, who under God, effected the Restoration of the Royal Family, and even of their very King James himself; the Reader may be pleased to peruse the Clause itself, and Judge of the reasonableness and Civility of it.

And whereas by one private Act of Parliament, Entituled, An Act for securing of several Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments to George Duke of Albemarle, which Act was past in the Reign of King Charles the Second, some Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments on this Kingdom, which on the Two and Twentieth day of October, 1641, belonged to some ancient Proprietor or Proprietors, who were dispossessed thereof by the late Usurped Powers, were secured or assured unto the said George Duke of Albemarle, by means whereof, the ancient Proprietors of the said Lands may be barred and deprived of their ancicnt Estates, unless the said Act be Repealed; though such ancient Proprietor or Proprietors, be as justly Intituled to Restitution, as other ancient Proprietors, who were dispossessed by the said Usurper, and barred by the late Acts of Settlement and Explanation. Be it therefore Enacted, That the said Act for securing of several Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments to George Duke of Albemarle, be and is hereby Repealed to all intents and purposes whatsoever; and that the Proprietors of the said Lands and their Heirs and Assigns be restored to their said ancient Estates in the same manner, with the said other ancient Proprietors, their Heirs and Assigns.

If any of the ancient Proprietors, (i. e.) the Heirs of those Barbarous Rebels, (who in 1641, exceeded the sharpest Turkish Cruelty) have been so thirsty as to purchase their old Estates, or any part of them, they shall be reprised, and reinburst their purchase Mony out of some honest Gentlemans Estate, and this surely was Mony well laid out. Viz.

And whereas, several ancient Proprietors whose Estates were seized and vested in Persons deriving a Title under the said Acts of Settlement or Explanation, have in some time after the passing the said Acts, purchased their own ancient Estates or parts thereof, from the Persons who held the same under the said Acts as aforesaid, which old Proprietors would now be restored to their said antient Estates, if they had not purchased the same. And for as much as the said ancient Proprietors or their Heirs, should receive no benefit of the said Act of Repeal, should they not be reprized for the Mony paid by them for their said ancient Estates.

Be it therfore Enacted by the Authority aforesaid, That all and every the ancient Proprietor or Proprietors, or their Heirs, who have laid out any Sum or Sums of Mony for the purchase of their own ancient Estates, or any part thereof as aforesaid, shall receive out of the Common▪ stock of Reprisals, a sufficient recompence and satisfaction▪ for the Mony laid out by him or them for the purchase of their said ancient Estate, at the rate of Ten Years purchase, any Clause, Act or Statute to the contrary in any wise notwithstanding.

Such as that Serene Government has been pleased to mark with the names of Rebels, are tyed to a certain fix'd time for procuring Certificates of their Innocence, and Inrolling their Pardons, though at the same time the Commissioners and other Ministers may chuse whether or no they will grant either, till the time (allowed) be elapsed; but in the case where the other good Subjects, i. e. the Blood-suckers of 1641, their Heirs or Assigns
are delayed in obtaining Letters Patents pursuant to the Act of Repeal, there a Certificate shall be of as great force, and bear the same Authority as Letters Patents under the Broad Seal, as appears by what follows.

And for prevention of all unnecessary Delays, and unjust Charges which can or may happen to the Subjects of this Realm, (viz. the Rebels of 1641. their Heirs and Assigns) before their full and final Setlement, Be it therefore Enacted by the Authority aforesaid, That where the Commissioners for Execution of the said Act of Repeal, or any three or more of them, shall give any Certificate under his or their Hands and Seals, to any Person or Persons, Bodies Politick or Corporate, in order to the passing any Letters Patents according to the said Act, and shall likewise return a Duplicate of such Certificate unto his Majesties Court of Exchequer at Dublin to be there enrolled, and the Person and Persons, Bodies Politick or Corporate, to whom such Certificate shall be given, shall during the space of six Months next ensuing the date thereof, dilligently prosecute the having and obtaining Letters Patents accordingly, but shall be thereof delayed and hindred by the neglect of any Officer or Officers, that then and in such Case the several and respective Person, Bodies Politick and Corporate, to whom or in whose behalf such Certificate shall be given or granted, shall hold and enjoy the several Messuages, Mannors, Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments in the several and respective Certificates mentioned and allotted according to such Estate, and under such Rent as are therein mentioned, as fully and amply to all intents and purposes, as if Letters Patents thereof had been granted and perfected according to the direction of the said former Act, any thing in this or the said former Act, or any other Law, Statute or Usage to the contrary notwithstanding. That those dutiful Subjects may have no cause of complaint, see the following Clause, viz.

And whereas by the hardships and Oppressions introduced by the said Acts of Settlement and Explanation, some ancient Proprietors who would have been restorable by the said Act of Repeal, have been necessitated to accept of Leases for Life, Lives, or Years, or Gifts in Tail, or other Conveyances of their respective Estates, and have contracted to pay some Rents, Duties, or other Reservations out of such their ancient Estates, by which acceptance of Leases, or Gifts before mentioned, and by the said Agreements to pay Rents, Duties or Reservations for the same; the said ancient Proprietors may be barred, or stopped, and excluded from the benefit of Restitution intended for ancient Proprietors, by the said Act of Repeal.

Be it therefore Enacted, that the acceptance of any such Lease or Leases, Gift or Gifts intail, or other Agreement or Agreements upon any such account for payment of Rents, Duties, or other Reservation for any such their ancient respective Estate or Estates shall be no way prejudicial, or binding, or conclusive to any such ancient Proprietors, or to his or their Heirs, Executors or Administrators, any thing herein, or in the said Act of Repeal to the contrary notwithstanding.

In a Word to render the Complyance of the Protestants (if any were so minded) altogether impossible; it is provided that all Letters to be granted of any Office, or Lands, shall contain a Clause, compelling the Inrolment in the Chancery in Ireland, viz. And it is further Enacted by the Authority aforesaid, That all Letters Patents hereafter to be granted of any Office or Lands whatsoever, shall contain in the same Letters Patents, a Clause requiring and compelling the said Patentees to cause the said Letters Patents to be enrolled in the Chancery of Ireland, within a time therein to be limited, and Letters Patents wherein such Clauses be omitted, are hereby declared to be utterly void and of none effect.

By the subsequent Clause they gave their King a Power
to the 1st day of Nov. 1689. to pardon, with this Restriction, that the said Letters Patents of Pardon, shall be enrolled in the Rolls Office of the Chancery in Ireland before the last of Nov. 1689. or else to be void and of none effect; a thing that was never known or whispered in England, or in the Protestant Quarters in Ireland till the Year 1690. and that the Master of the Rolls, and that obliging Attorny General of whom you have had a short Discription, page may not be hopeless of good Griest to their Mills, it is provided, that no Letters Patents of Pardon may contain above one Person: And that the Reader may be Judge of the Matter of Fact, here it begins thus:

Provided always, That if your Sacred Majesty at any time before the first day of November 1689. by Letters Patents under the Broad Seal of England residing there, or by Letters Patents under the Broad Seal of Ireland during your▪ Majesties aboad here, shall grant your gracious Pardon or Pardons to any one or more of the Persons herein before mentioned, or intended to be attainted, who shall return to their Duty and Loyalty, that then, and in such case, such Person and Persons so pardoned, shall be, and are hereby excepted out of this present Act, as if they never had been therein named, or thereby intended to be attainted, and shall be, and are hereby acquitted and discharged from all Attainders, Penalties and Forfeitures created or inflicted by this Act, or the said Act of Repeal, Excepting such share or proportion of their Real or Personal Estates as your Majesty shall think fit to except or reserve from them; any thing in this present Act, or in the said Act of Repeal to the contrary notwithstanding.

Provided always, that every such Pardon or Pardons be pursuant to a Warrant under your Majesties privy Signet, or Sign Manual, and that no one Letters Patents of Pardon shall contain above one Person; And that all and every such Letters Patents of Pardon and Pardons shall be inrolled in the Rolls Office in your Majesties
High Court of Chancery in this Kingdom (of Ireland) at or before the said last day of the said Month of November, or indefault thereof, to be absolutely void and of no effect, any thing herein contained to the contrary notwithstanding.

Provided likewise, that if any Person or Persons so pardoned, shall at any time after the date of the said Pardon, joyn with, or aid, or assist any of your Majesties Enemies, or with any Rebels in any of your Majesties Dominions, and be thereof convicted or attainted by any due Course of Law, that then, and in such case they shall forfeit all the benefit and advantage of such Pardon, and shall be again subject and lyable to all penalties and Forfeitures inflicted on them, and every of them by this or the said Act of Repeal; as if such Pardon or Pardons had never been granted; Provided always, that nothing in this Act contained shall extend, or be construed to extend to vest in your Majesty any Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments, or other interest of any ancient Proprietor, who by the said Act of Repeal is to be restored to his ancient Estate, but that all such Person or Persons, and all the Right, Title and Interest are, and shall be saved, and reserved according to the true intent and meaning of the said Act, any thing in these Presents to the contrary notwithstanding.
Dublin Jan. 24th. 1689. Examined per L. Lealby.

And now by what's here truly Copied out of their Originals, and from the short Remarks made thereupon; I hope the Reader will not think it tedious or improper by way of Conclusion, to give a summary Account of some late Transactions in and about Dublin, and the Misery the Protestants were in, both there and in the Country; The late King's tame Submission, and truckling to the French, their Insolency, Pride and Haughtiness, as well to the Papists as Protestants, and many other Passages.

From that time, the Lord Mayor put his witty trick on the Country People about their Corn, &c. It was observed that the Markets were very ill furnished, and seldom Five Barrels of any kind of Grain seen on any Market Day. Then it's agreed on in their Councils to Erect publick Stores through the Kingdom, for gathering in Wheat, Malt, and all sorts of Grain, and also for Leather, Wool, Butter, Cheese, and what else they thought fit; and under pretence of furnishing and filling Stores, to support an Army, (as you see in the Proclamation for that end,) Seized all the visible effects of those poor Protestants that were under their wings, sending such quantities of all sorts to France as the Ingrosser pleased. The late King was not the only Merchant, but under his License many Transported great quantities; as Delabody had a License for Fifteen Thousand Pound value. Many of the Dealers knowing it to be Felony to Transport Wool into France, were cautious how they dealt in that Commodity; it was hoped that some of them that were taken by King William's Fleet, would be made Examples to deter others from falling into the like Errour.

Before March last, they had Seized above Thirty Thousand Barrels of Wheat within two Miles of Dublin, and Six Thousand Barrels in the County of West-Meath, besides other sorts of Grain; and we heard that the like Methods had been put in Execution in all parts of the Kingdom under their Power. One Mr. Babe, Surveyer General, was commanded to Seise all the Malt in Dublin for the King's use, which he disobeying, as not belonging to his Office, and unwilling to Plunder his Fellow Protestants, was displaced as a Dis-affected Person, and one put in that would observe Popish Orders.

By Ingrossing the Corn and other Provisions, it was believed and said by some of the Popish Party, that it was to Starve all the Protestants; and some of them swore in Coffee-Houses, it would never be well with the good Catholick Subjects, till the one half of
the Protestants were Hanged and the other half Starved.

Some others say, that nothing should be sold out of the Stores to the Protestants, but for Gold and Silver, by which means they would certainly get it; for although they have tryed many ways, yet none look'd so effectual as this, unless putting them to the Rack and their Oaths to discover what Silver or Gold they had; with which they have been long threatned, though some Providence has still averted it. Flesh was sold at Six Pence a Pound, and all provisions very dear; yet there was enough to be had for Mony, till the Markets were abused by wheedling and foolish Proclamations.

The Protestants in the Country having some foresight of the scarcity they might endure, and remembring the miseries some of them had seen, and some others had heard their Ancestors endured in 1641, thought it prudence to provide good Stores of Hang'd Beef, Bacon, Dryed Fish, Pease and Beans, which by order from the Government (under the name of Seizing) was by the Souldiers plunder taken from them. Some others of them having got Brass Mony, laid it out on Wool, Hides, Butter Cheese, and Tallow, which was likewise taken from them; and when those Poor, Naked, Pillaged Creatures sought redress, they were mock'd and scoft at by those that gave orders to plunder them.

Such of the old Proprietors as pretended any claim to the Estates of the Absentees, they took Leases from the Commissioners for Executing the Act of Repeal; and about May last, when they were to be put in Possession, they held on, and so prevented the Sheriffs trouble.

Such of the Protestants as were resolved to abide and endure the brunt of things, care was taken to frighten them away; the Government issues a secret Order to the several Lieutenants of the Counties, to turn the Protestants out of such Estates as the Papists had any claim to, and put them in, who were sure would not let the Protestants
carry away one Pennyworth of their Goods, keeping them as some satisfaction for the mean profits. Thus they dealt with the Lord Primate (Boyl,) who lost about Ten Thousand Pound value in the furniture of his House at Blessington, and Killed all the Deer in his Park, though the Flesh at that time was of no use; this was not so much to be admired, when by authority under the Government, they Destroyed all the Deer in Rafernum Park, and in the Park by Chappell-Izzard.

And if yet some of the Protestants remained on their Estates, to which those old Proprietors could make no Claim, on those the Lieutenants by the aforesaid Order might quarter Soldiers at discretion, which they did to the great grief of those Gentlemen, who as long as they could, gave free Quarters to such Numbers as were placed on them; but not being able to endure this Oppression and the abuses put on themselves, Wives and Children, were forced to fly with their Lives. And this exceeded even the French Dragooning; thus to be forced to abandon their fair Buildings, Orchards, and other Improvements, was more untollerable, than the loss of what was taken from them before, hoping in time to recover some of their Estates and other Losses, but never their Improvements; which those Ruffians (knowing their Reign to be but short) designedly defaced, rooted up, burnt and destroyed, and which had been brought to yield profit as well as pleasure by great Charge and Industry, since the Settlement after 1641. Who would not be afflicted thus to be turned out, to make room for his Cow-boy or Swine-Herd, and see them decide his Mansion House into Seven or Eight several Dwellings, for those Brutes whose Fore-Fathers never lay on any other or better Bed than a few green Rushes, or a little Straw, and after this manner have they divided that noble Building of Eyres-Court in the County of Gallway.

The Protestants being persecuted from Place to Place in the Country, at length fled to Dublin, where indeed to say
truth, the Protestant Citizens have been so liberal, both to the Protestant Prisoners, and those that were not, that it is to be admired how their Purses held out; at one Collection on a Sabbath day, it was usual to receive Fifty or Sixty Pound, and had it not been for such large Collections, it had gone hard with the Country Gentry, who had not received any Rent from May 1688, and always Improving their Estates, kept but little Money by them, which they were forced to spend in the defence of Law Suits, and other vexatious troubles put on them by the Implacable Papists; and those that after all had saved some in considerable Sum, which though never so thriftily managed, yet by the scarcity and dearness of things in Dublin, it was soon spent, and thence they became greater Objects, as being really in a worse condition than the meaner sort, who could work for Victuals; however as soon as their Poverty was made known, (which was not before they had almost perished,) there was a competent Dividend of the publick Collection sent by a private hand; and thus by the mutual sense and Fellow-feeling of our Distresses, we supported one another.

That Order sent to the Lieutenants of the several Counties, to quarter Men and Horses at Discretion on the Protestants, was never shew'd to any of us, so that we could never come by a Copy of it; but yet they freely told us the Contents, and put them in Execution, with all the severity imaginable, to our great Grief and Loss never to be repaired.

By the late King's being in Possession of Dublin, the Metropolis of the Kingdom, gained great credit with France, though it has been used as if designed for Flames, when no longer tenable by the late King and his Adherents; Fifty Thousand Pounds would not Repair the Damage done to the Buildings thereof before March last; without opening of a Gate or Door, one might have walked, nay almost rid from one end to the other of the Colledge.

A brisk Trade was kept up with the French, who sent great quantities of Fruit, Wine, Brandy, Hops, Tobacco, and other gross Commodities; for which they carried away the best that was in Ireland, as Butter, Cheese, Wooll, raw Hides and Tallow; the late King released 11 l. 10 s. Imposition on every Tun of Wine, and this was done in favour of his Army, who before paid Two Shillings a Quart, and then but one.

The 14th of April, when Sir Clously Shovel appeared before Dublin with the Fleet under his Command, great quantities of the Protestants Goods being Seized, and several Ships Loaded, and a Loading with them, the late King and his Crew were under terrible apprehensions at first, believing that some Land-Men would be sent from the Ships to Reduce Dublin, but seeing they only attacked the Ships in the Pool, and fearing they might come into the Harbour where the Loaded Ships lay, all Hands were imployed to unload; but Sir Clously going off with a smaller Prise than was expected, and the Coast being clear, all Hands were again made use of to Load all the Ships in the Harbour with the Protestants Goods; which being done, they set Sail under the Convoy of the late King's whole Fleet, consisting of Four Ships, one of Eighteen Guns, one of Sixteen, one of Twelve Guns, and a French Privateer. That shew made by Sir Clously, had like to have been fatal to the Protestants, whose Countenance being somewhat chearful, immediately it was proclaimed Death to a Protestant found out of Doors; on some it fell heavily, as upon a Gentleman of my Acquaintance being on a Visit among some Relations in the Inns beyond the Bridge, not knowing the danger, going homeward, was stopp'd on Essex Bridge, receiving a Cut above Seven Inches long on his Head, which for Two Years before, aked most violently, but to his great ease, the same pain has not visited him since his Recovery. And what were we to have in exchange for all those choice Commodities? Arms and Ammunition to Murder us; and indeed we could
expect no other, that being the Exchange agreed upon before-hand.

Silver and Gold became one of the greatest and best Commodities in Dublin; between Buyer and Seller, a Guinea before May last was sold at 3 l. 10 s. and an Ounce of Silver at Three Crowns of Brass Mony, and so proportionable for other quantities of Gold and Silver. And although the French brought great quantities of Brass and Copper, yet it was not enough; so that they began to reduce the Weights of what was already Coined, by melting it down, and making it less in the new Coin; the value of Brass Mony fell daily, before March Six Hundred Thousand Pounds was Coined.

The Mint has been of late altogether managed by Protestants; some time since there being Papists in one branch, were discovered to cheat above Five Hundred Pound a Week in the Six-pences, for which they were slightly punished, and so turned off; which had been Death in a Protestant. And not only in this, but in all other common ordinary Affairs, the Protestants were forced to contrive things for the Papists.

The necessary Charge of the Army, came to Eleven Hundred Thousand Pound per Annum, and the Revenue of the Kingdom never came to above Three Hundred Thirty Two Thousand Pounds per Annum; therefore, if the late King had been pay'd all he could pretend to, the Twenty Thousand Pounds Subsidy would not half sustain'd his Army; so that of necessity there must have been Coined Yearly, Six Hundred Thousand Pounds in Brass Mony, which having no way to circulate, must be so much Loss to the Kingdom, and in short time come to nothing. But to prevent this, he offered to pledge or pawn his Quit-Rent, for Brass Mony, at Six per Cent; but no body has trusted him.

Whilst this Brass Mony past, it was of extraordinary benefit to the Distressed Protestants, all that had it, were ready to Lend those that wanted, otherwise some Hundreds would have perished, that through meer shame could not discover their condition, to receive of the publick Charity.

Of late the Protestants could not come by a bit of Bread, but what they purchased at triple rates from the Soldiers, a Dozen or Twenty of them being placed about every Bakers House to prevent the Protestants from coming by any; of which cruel dealings, the late King being informed, he answered that his Army must not want Bread whosoever did; this was some of his tenderness to his Protestant Subjects; but they made one shift or other to get it till the French came, and I fear from thence, many were Starved for want of Bread.

The Protestant Tradesmen were all Imployed, though they had rather sate Idle, being ill payed for their Labour, and that in Brass Mony, which they freely gave to their Fellow Sufferers that wanted most.

From the whole, it is easy to observe the Case of the Protestants to be very deplorable, being Robbed and Plundered of all they had in the World, enslaved and subjected to those they hated and despised. And although the late King or his Army, could not subsist one day without the Protestants, yet were they nevertheless abused, slighted, opprest, and had more barbarous usage than could been expected from Algereens; we were sensible they only spared our Lives whilst serviceable to them, and afterwards our certain Destruction was designed: In the mean time, the Protestants were forced to strengthen and support their Enemies.

If the Protestant Butchers, Brewers, Bakers, Clothiers, Weavers, Taylors, Shooe-makers, Hat-makers, Smiths, Carpenters, and other Artizens, had been removed from
them, they could not have had Meat, Bread or Drink, Cloaths to wear, nor Carts to carry Provision, Arms or Ammunition into▪ the Fields; nor would the late King had a Mint, Brass or Copper to Coin in it: so that they had suspended all thoughts of turning out the Protestants, as it was often moved in their Councils. The Governour▪ Luttorel told the French Ambassador, that if the Protestants were turned out of Dublin, the Papists must quit it; and when they quitted Dublin, they must quit Ireland. It was the City that almost maintained and supported the late King's Army last Winter, it being able to quarter above Twenty Thousand Men at one time: And therefore it was no wonder they were unwilling to part with such a Place. But however the matter went, they were resolved as soon as King William took the Field, to confine all the Protestants to the Churches, Hospitals and Goals, which it seems they did; and which was their common practice on every slight Alarm.

About the Twelfth of March last, the French Fleet consisting of about Forty Men of War, and about Sixty Tenders and others, came into Cork Harbour, with about Five Thousand French Land-men; for which as you have heard, as many of the Brave Old Heroick Bogtrotters were to be sent to the French King; but many of them according to their usual custom run away, in the place of whom many Protestants were Pressed for that Service to their great grief. It was then discoursed, that as soon as they returned to France, an Additional Fleet would Join them, and that they intended to bring Ten Thousand Land Men with them for the late Kin'gs Service; which doubtless is the Fleet on our Coasts. Some of the Nobility about the late King, discoursing of the English and French, said they to him, Sir, Is not the French Fleet in great danger to be met with by the English; to which he Replied, That he during his time, had taken
care that the English should not have any great strength by Sea; and now to equip and fit out a Fleet, would be tedious, besides the expences; and that he did not doubt but the French would master them; the French had not been well landed at Cork when some pestilent Distemper carryed off above five hundred of them, they soon began to murmur, saying, They were promised great Matters before they left France, of which, since their coming they saw but small appearance, about three Months Pay in Silver and Gold was sent with them from France, which was of a very course Metal, and a third part less in the intrinsick Value, than as it formerly past in Ireland.

Three Battalions of the French marched towards Dublin, appointed as General Lauzuns Guards; the late King having promised his Guardian (i. e.) the French King, that the French General should have the possession of Dublin, and of all the places of any Strength in Ireland; accordingly on the the 3d of May Lauzun sent to the Governor Lutterel to deliver the Keys of the City and Castle, to whom Lutterel answered, he would first acquaint the King, who forthwith accompanied the Lord Mayor and Aldermen to address the King, telling him they had thitherto ventur'd their Lives and Fortunes in his Defence, and therefore hoped he would not still confide in them to govern Dublin, and would not make them absolute Subjects to the French, to whom he reply'd, That he had engaged, and past his Word to his Brother Lewis, that Lauzun should have the Government of Dublin, and could not recede from it; thereupon the Keys of the City was delivered, but the French would not mount the Guards till they had likewise the Keys of the Castle, which being also comply'd with, on the fourth of May, the French possest themselves of City and Castle, swearing they had no King but Lewis, nor would they obey any other, and under him their General Lauzun: from thence they grew so very Rude and Insolent, not only
to Protestants, but to Papists, that the later grew mighty melancholy and dejected, frequently complaining to their King, who had no power to help himself or them, having by his degenerate and mean Spirit truckl'd his Authority, and became subject to the power of France, and contented himself to be nominal King.

Of which, the better and more sober sort of Papists were sensible (foreseeing a suddain change of Government) could never be perswaded to take on them the least Office or Employment under him, even that of Constable, but resolved to lay hold on the first Opportunity, and throw themselves at the Mercy of our most Gracious King, which ere now they have had a good opportunity to embrace.

And though how ill soever the Irish Papists resented the Insolence of the French, yet the Majority were resolved to bear with all rather than by expressing their inward dislike or discontent, giving encouragement to the Protestants, to hope for any advantage that might happen from Discords among Papists, and therefore carest and treated the French, who called them ten thousand Cowards, and said, they were beaten by a Priest and a few Boys, meaning that valiant Colonel Walker, and those matchless Hero's that suffer'd with him.

There being above ten thousand Protestant Men in Dublin able to bear Arms, besides Women and Children, and being barr'd of the liberty of the Markets by the French, who would not sell Bread to the Protestants as the Irish Papist Soldiers did; it is a Miracle if thousands the Protestants had not perished.

The French as they past by any of our Clergy, threatened them sadly; on which the Clergy held frequent Consultations how to secure themselves, and deliver'd their poor Flocks from the daily Threats and Menaces of the French Vultures.

It was moved that the Clergy should disguise themselves in Frieze Coats, not finding it probable to escape the then impending Dangers in their Gowns; this Motion was rejected by the Majority, and still depending on his Protection, who stills the Winds, and the raging of the Seas.

The French had not been two days in Dublin when they murdered two or three Protestant Clothiers, in a part of the City called the Comb; for that great Crime of protecting their Wives from being made Prostitutes to the French, of which Inhuman Act no notice was ever taken, more than if two Dogs had been, shot. About the same time some of them took a Country-Maid that came to Market with her Father, and defloured her in the open Street at Noon-day. Many such barbarous pieces of Villany has been perpetrated by those Blood-suckers, whose continual Practice was in all Parts of the World where they have been, to burn and demolish such Places as were not tenable by them; and so they moved in their Councils, that that famous City of Dublin should be dealt with; first to shut up the Protestants in the Churches and Hospitals, and then if they lost the day, to set Fire to all, whereby not only the City, but the Protestants also should be destroyed; whereupon the Irish City Papists, and those of the Army apply'd themselves to their King, and told him they should suffer in that Expedition, as well as the Protestants; and that they would not draw a Sword in his Defence, unless all thoughts of burning the City were set aside, and declared that as soon as they saw or heard of any appearance of Fire, they would fly from his Service and submit to King Williams Mercy, of which, now they have had a good Experiment, and we hope to have that account of those usurping, intruding Ruffians, which Count D'avaux prophesied at the landing of General Lauzun and the French; said D'avaux to Lauzun, You are come
to be a Sacrifice for a poor spirited and cowardly People, whose Souldiers will never Fight, and whose Officers would never observe Orders, and therefore they would meet with the same Fate his Masters Army met with at the Siege of Candia, that is, to be wasted and destroyed, those that came to relieve not standing by them; and thus we see the wonderful Work of God (who has protected the Protestants in Dublin) delivered them from Pharoah and his Hosts on the fourth day of this Instant July. Our gracious Deliverer King William, and his Royal Consort Queen Mary were proclaimed KING and QUEEN in Dublin, by the command, and in the presence of his Grace the Duke of Ormond, without any great loss on our side, and with wonderful satisfaction, and unexpressible Joy to those poor Protestants, who were upon the same Day released from their Bondage.
